questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes Type I and Type II errors in hypothesis testing?

choices.text: Type I rejects a true null hypothesis; Type II accepts a false null hypothesis.
Type I accepts a false null hypothesis; Type II rejects a true null hypothesis.
Type I rejects a true alternative hypothesis; Type II accepts a false alternative hypothesis.
Type I: Accepting a true null hypothesis; Type II: Rejecting a false null hypothesis.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Type I rejects a true null hypothesis; Type II accepts a false null hypothesis.

Explanation:

Criteria

Type I Error

Type II Error

Definition

Rejecting a true null hypothesis

Accepting a false null hypothesis

Also Known As

False positive.

False-negative.

Implication

Concluding there is an effect when there is none.

Concluding there is no effect when there is one.

Probability Notation

Alpha (Œ±)

Beta (Œ≤)

Consequences

Believing a result is significant when it is not.

Missing a significant result.

Example

Concluding a drug has an effect when it does not.

Concluding a drug does not have an effect when it does.

Testing Goal

Minimise Œ± to reduce the Type I error rate.

Minimise Œ≤ to reduce the Type II error rate.

questions.text: Which of the following is statistically significant?

choices.text: RR of 2.5 with a 95% CI of 2.0 to 3.1
OR of 0.9 with a 95% CI of 0.5 to 8
p-value of 0.5 and a RR of 2.5.
RR of 5.0 with a 95% CI of 0.1 to 9.8

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) RR of 2.5 with a 95% CI of 2.0 to 3.1

Explanation:

A 95% Confidence interval (CI) of 2.0 to 3.1 suggests that the relative risk of 2.5 is statistically significant because the CI does not include 1.

Level of significance:

  • Null hypothesis is accepted / results are not statistically significant when
    • 95% CI for the mean difference between 2 variables includes 0
    • 95% CI for odds ratio or relative risk includes 1
    • CI between 2 groups do not overlap ‚Üí statistically significant difference exists.

Option B) An odd‚Äôs ratio of 0.9 with a 95% Confidence interval of 0.5 to 8:

The CI includes 1, meaning there is no significant difference and hence not statistically significant.

Option C) A p-value of 0.5 and a relative risk of 2.5:

The p-value is >0.05 hence it is not statistically significant.

Option: D) A relative risk of 5.0 with a 95% Confidence interval of 0.1 to 9.8:

The CI includes 1, meaning the results are not statistically significant.

questions.text: A public health researcher is studying the average weight of newborns in a specific region. The researcher collects a random sample of 100 newborns and calculates a 95% confidence interval for the mean weight (3.2 kg, 3.8 kg). Which of the following statements correctly interprets the 95% confidence level?

choices.text: There is a 95% chance that the mean weight of all newborns in the region falls between 3.2 kg and 3.8 kg
95% of the newborns in the sample weigh between 3.2 kg and 3.8 kg.
95 % of the intervals will include the true mean if we calculate CI for multiple samples
Mean weight of all newborns in the region is exactly 3.5 kg, which is the midpoint of the confidence interval.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 95 % of the intervals will include the true mean if we calculate CI for multiple samples

Explanation:

Confidence interval:

The confidence interval is the range of values within which the true mean of the population is expected to fall with a specified probability.

Confidence Level:

A 95% confidence level means that if we take many random samples and compute a confidence interval for each, we expect 95% of those intervals to contain the true population mean.

Formula to calculate the confidence interval:

  • 95% Confidence interval for mean = mean ¬± 2 x standard error of mean
  • 95% Confidence interval for proportion = p ¬± 2 x standard error of proportion

Option A: There is a 95% chance that the mean weight of all newborns in the region falls between 3.2 kg and 3.8 kg. This is incorrect because the confidence interval does not give the probability of the population mean being within the interval.

Option B: 95% of the newborns in the sample have weights between 3.2 kg and 3.8 kg. This is incorrect because the confidence interval pertains to the mean weight, not the distribution of individual weights within the sample.

Option D: The mean weight of all newborns in the region is exactly 3.5 kg, the midpoint of the confidence interval. This is incorrect because the confidence interval indicates a range of values for the population mean, not a specific value.

questions.text: A study was conducted to determine the effectiveness of a new antihypertensive. The study is designed with a significance level (alpha) of 0.05 and a sample size of 50 participants. The type II error is calculated as 0.25. Which of the following is the power of this study, and how can it be increased?

choices.text: The power of the study is 75% and can be increased by decreasing the sample size.
The power of the study is 70%, and it can be increased by increasing the sample size.
The power of the study is 75% and it can be increased by increasing the sample size.
The power of the study is 95% and it can be increased by increasing the sample size.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) The power of the study is 75%, and it can be increased by increasing the sample size.

Explanation:

The power of a study is calculated as:

Power = 1- Œ≤

From the above result, Œ≤¬†(Type II error) = 0.25

Hence power = 1 - 0.25 = 0.75 or 75%

Power and type II error:

  • Type II error (beta) occurs when the null hypothesis is false but accepted.
  • The power of a test can be increased by decreasing the Type II error, i.e. by increasing the sample size.

questions.text: A health researcher is testing the effectiveness of a new drug in reducing blood pressure. The null hypothesis (H0) is that the drug does not affect blood pressure, while the alternative hypothesis (H1) is that the drug does reduce blood pressure. After conducting the study and analysing the data, the researcher calculates a p-value of 0.03. Based on this information, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Probability of the null hypothesis being accepted is 3%.
Observed effect has a less than 3% chance of occurring by random chance.
Probability of the null hypothesis being rejected is 3%.
Observed effect has a 97% chance of occurring due to the new drug

questions.solution:
Correct¬† Answer: A) Probability of the null hypothesis being accepted is 3%.

Explanation: There is less than 3% chance that the observed effect is due to random variation.

A p-value of 0.03 means that there is a less than 3% probability that the observed effect occurred by chance, which suggests that the outcome of the study is statistically significant

p-value:

  • It is the probability of committing a Type 1 error
  • Maximum threshold for committing a Type 1 error is set at 5%
  • When the p-value is less than Œ±, the result is statistically significant. (p<0.05)
  • It only tells us about the strength of evidence against the null hypothesis based on the observed data.

questions.text: What does the p-value represent in hypothesis testing?

choices.text: Probability that a Type 2 error is being made.
Probability of declaring a significant difference when there is none in reality.
Probability of declaring a significant difference when it is present.
It represents power and is equal to 1 - Beta.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B. Probability of declaring a significant difference when there is none in reality

Explanation:

  • The p-value in hypothesis testing represents the probability of obtaining the observed data or more extreme results, assuming that the null hypothesis is true.
  • It helps researchers determine the strength of the evidence against the null hypothesis; a lower p-value indicates stronger evidence.
  • The maximum value for committing a Type 1 error is 5%. This is known as the Œ± level of significance
  • p-value can be less, equal or more than …ë, but the p-value has to be less than …ë(p < 0.05) to be statistically significant.

questions.text: A weighing scale consistently adds 10% to each weight. A true weight of 10 kg is 11 kg, while a true weight of 40 kg is 44 kg. Which type of error is exhibited in this scenario?

choices.text: Random error
Non-random error
Human error
Operator error

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Non-random error

Explanation:

Criteria

Random Error

Non Random Error

Definition

Unpredictable variations in measurements due to chance factors

Consistent or predictable deviations from the true value

Nature of Variation

Causes measurements to fluctuate randomly around the true value

Causes measurements to deviate in one direction consistently.

Cause

Typically due to

  • Random chance
  • Environmental factors
  • Sampling variability

Often due

  • Instrumental error
  • Methodological error
  • Calibration error

Effect on Measurements

Increases measurement variability across repeated trials.

Introduces a consistent bias or offset from the true value.

Reduction Strategy

This can be reduced by increasing sample size or conducting more trials

Requires adjustments to measurement tools, recalibration, or procedural changes

Examples

Fluctuations in experimental readings despite controlled conditions.

A scale consistently adding 10% to all weights measured.

questions.text: A new drug designed to lower cholesterol levels is being tested. The testing involved 1000 participants. The null hypothesis is that "the new drug does not affect cholesterol levels". After analysing the data, the researchers conclude that the drug doesn't work, but in reality, it does have a small but clinically significant effect. What type of error has occurred?

choices.text: Type I error
Type II error
No error has occurred
Both Type I and Type II errors

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Type II error

¬†

Explanation:

This scenario describes a Type II error, also known as a "false negative."

  • The null hypothesis states the drug has no effect.
  • In reality, the drug does have an effect (the null hypothesis is false).
  • The researchers fail to reject the null hypothesis

Key points:

  • Type II error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis.
  • It results in missing a real effect or relationship.
  • In this case, a potentially beneficial drug might be overlooked.
  • Type II errors are particularly important in medical research, as they can lead to overlooking potentially beneficial treatments.
  • The power of a statistical test (1 - probability of Type II error) is crucial in designing studies to minimise this risk.

Type I error (Option A): A Type I error occurs when you reject a true null hypothesis. In this scenario, the researchers concluded the drug doesn't work (failed to reject the null), but it actually does have an effect. This is the opposite of a Type I error.

No error has occurred (Option C): An error clearly occurred because the researchers' conclusion (drug doesn't work) contradicts the reality (drug does work).

Both Type I and Type II errors (Option D): It is impossible to commit both a Type I and a Type II error in the same hypothesis test for the same null hypothesis.

questions.text: In a clinical trial for a new hypertension drug, the null hypothesis states: "The new drug does not affect blood pressure." If researchers commit a Type 1 error, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Drug lower BP, but it was concluded that it has no effect.
Drug has no effect, but it was concluded as it lowers BP.
Drug raises BP, but it was concluded that it has no effect.
Drug has no effect, and it was correctly concluded.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Drug has no effect, but it was concluded as it lowers BP

Explanation: A Type 1 error, also known as a "false positive," occurs when we reject the null hypothesis when it is true. In this case:

  • Null hypothesis: The drug does not affect blood pressure.
  • Type 1 error: Rejecting this true null hypothesis and accepting an alternative hypothesis.

Key points:

  • In a Type 1 error, the truth aligns with the null hypothesis (the drug truly has no effect).
  • The error lies in the researchers' conclusion, which incorrectly rejects the null hypothesis.
  • This error leads to a false claim of a significant effect when there isn't one.

Criteria

Type II Error

Rejecting a true null hypothesis

Accepting a false null hypothesis

False-negative.

Implication

Concluding there is an effect when there is none.

Concluding there is no effect when there is one.

Probability Notation

Alpha (Œ±)

Beta (Œ≤)

Consequences

Believing a result is significant when it is not.

Missing a significant result.

Example

Concluding a drug has an effect when it does not.

Concluding a drug does not have an effect when it does.

Testing Goal

Minimise Œ± to reduce the Type I error rate.

Minimise Œ≤ to reduce the Type II error rate.

questions.text: The blood pressure measurement of 120 patients was conducted in a health camp. The first quartile systolic blood pressure was 108 mm Hg, and the third quartile was 136 mm Hg. How many people will have their BP between the 1st and 3rd quartile?

choices.text: 30 patients
60 patients
90 patients
75 patients

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 60 patients

Explanation:

Total number of patients = 120

Q1= 108 mm hg

Q3= 136 mm hg

We know,

Quartiles divide the data set into 4 equal parts.

Q1 is the point below which 25% of the data falls, and Q3 is below which 75% falls.

If,

25 % of people have systolic BP less than 108 mm Hg = 30 people

75% of people have systolic BP less than or equal to 136 mm Hg = 90 people

25% of people have systolic BP more than 136 mm Hg = 30 people

¬†

Thus

The number of people with BP between 108 and 136 mm Hg (i.e., between the 1st and 3rd quartile) is 75% - 25% = 50% of the total patients.

Hence, 50% * 120 = 60 patients will have their BP between the 1st and 3rd quartiles.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the coefficient of variation (COV)?

choices.text: COV compares the relative variability of datasets with different means.
Higher COV signifies greater dispersion relative to the mean, indicating lower reliability
Lower COV suggests data points are closer to the mean, indicating higher reliability.
COV can be negative if the standard deviation is smaller than the mean.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) COV can be negative if the standard deviation is smaller than the mean.

Explanation: The coefficient of variation (COV) is calculated as the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean, and both the standard deviation and the mean are non-negative quantities. Therefore, COV values are always non-negative and cannot be negative.

COV = œÉ/ mean x 100
  • The coefficient of variation (COV) is specifically designed to compare the variability of datasets with different means. (Option A)
  • It standardises the measure of dispersion by expressing the standard deviation as a percentage of the mean, allowing for meaningful comparison even when the datasets have different scales.
  • A higher COV signifies that the standard deviation is relatively larger than the mean, indicating greater variability or spread of data points around the mean and less reliable (Option B).

A lower COV indicates that the standard deviation is smaller than the mean, suggesting that data points are closer to the mean. This typically implies more consistency and less variability, which can indicate higher reliability of the dataset for analysis or decision-making. (Option C).
